{{for|the television episode|Nepotism (The Office)}} {{Political corruption sidebar}} '''Nepotism''' is based on favour granted to [[Kinship|relatives]] in various fields, including business, politics, entertainment, sports, religion and other activities.
The term originated with the assignment of nephews to important positions by [[Catholicism|Catholic]] [[pope]]s and [[bishop]]s.
==Origins== {{Main|Cardinal-nephew}} The term comes from Italian word ''nepotismo'',<ref name="dictionary">[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism "Nepotism."] Dictionary.com. Retrieved 20 June 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=In Praise of Nepotism: A Natural History |work=[[Adam Bellow]] Booknotes interview transcript |url=http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926013727/http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archivedate=26 September 2010 |accessdate=10 September 2013}} </ref> which is based on Latin root ''nepos'' meaning nephew.<ref>{{cite web |title=Article nepos |work=CTCWeb Glossary |url=http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |accessdate=10 September 2013}} </ref> Since the [[Middle Ages]] and until the late 17th century, some [[Catholicism|Catholic]] [[pope]]s and [[bishop]]s, who had taken vows of [[chastity]], and therefore usually had no legitimate offspring of their own, gave their nephews such positions of preference as were often accorded by fathers to son.<ref name="Article Nepotism">{{cite web|title=Article Nepotism |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://catholic-forum.com/saints/ncd05726.htm |accessdate=2007-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archivedate=February 24, 2007 }} </ref>
Several popes [[Cardinal-nephew|elevated nephews]] and other relatives to the [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinalate]]. Often, such appointments were a means of continuing a papal "dynasty".<ref>{{cite book|author1=Gianvittorio Signorotto|author2=Maria Antonietta Visceglia|title=Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492-1700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2W1tc-wf5DQC&pg=PA114|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=21 March 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43141-5|pages=114–116}}</ref> For instance, [[Pope Callixtus III]], head of the [[House of Borgia|Borgia]] family, made two of his nephews cardinals; one of them, Rodrigo, later used his position as a cardinal as a stepping stone to the papacy, becoming [[Pope Alexander VI]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Article Pope Alexander VI |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |accessdate=2007-07-12 }} </ref> Alexander then elevated Alessandro Farnese, his mistress's brother, to cardinal; Farnese would later go on to become [[Pope Paul III]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Article Pope Paul III |work=Catholic Encyclopedia |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |accessdate=2007-07-12 }} </ref>
Paul III also engaged in nepotism, appointing, for instance, two nephews, aged 14 and 16, as cardinals. The practice was finally limited when [[Pope Innocent XII]] issued the [[Papal bull|bull]] ''[[Romanum decet Pontificem]]'', in 1692.<ref name="Article Nepotism"/> The papal bull prohibited popes in all times from bestowing estates, offices, or revenues on any relative, with the exception that one qualified relative (at most) could be made a cardinal.<ref>{{cite book|author=Anura Gurugé|title=The Next Pope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5JVthemvvwC&pg=PA115|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=16 February 2010|publisher=Anura Guruge|isbn=978-0-615-35372-2|page=115}}</ref>
== Types ==
=== Political === Nepotism is a common accusation in politics when the relative of a powerful figure ascends to similar power seemingly without appropriate qualifications. The [[British English]] expression "[[Bob's your uncle]]" is thought to have originated when [[Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury]], promoted his nephew, [[Arthur Balfour]], to the esteemed post of [[Chief Secretary for Ireland]], which was widely seen as an act of nepotism.<ref name=Trahair>[https://books.google.com/books?id=K0zrsHO27-wC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72 ''From Aristotelian to Reaganomics: A Dictionary of Eponyms With Biographies in the Social Science''], by R. C. S. Trahair, [[Greenwood Publishing Group]], 1994, page 72. Retrieved online from [[Google Books]], Jul 30, 2012.</ref>
=== Organizational === Nepotism can also occur within organizations, when a person is employed due to their familial ties. It is generally seen as unethical, both on the part of the employer and employee.
==== In employment ==== Nepotism at work can mean increased opportunity at a job, attaining the job or being paid more than other similarly situated people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/nepotismatwork.html |title=Nepotism at Work |publisher=Safeworkers.co.uk |date=2013-04-20 |accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref> Arguments are made both for and against employment granted due to a family connection, which is most common in small, family run businesses. On one hand, nepotism can provide stability and continuity. Critics cite studies that demonstrate decreased morale and commitment from non-related employees,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |title=Family Ties: Handling Nepotism Within Your Business - Perspectives - Inside INdiana Business with Gerry Dick |publisher=Insideindianabusiness.com |date=2010-11-09 |accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref> and a generally negative attitude towards superior positions filled through nepotism. An article from ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine stated "there is no ladder to climb when the top rung is reserved for people with a certain name."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |title=Is Nepotism So Bad? |publisher=Forbes |date= |accessdate=2013-06-20 |first=Klaus |last=Kneale}}</ref> Some businesses forbid nepotism as an ethical matter, considering it too troublesome and disruptive.
====In entertainment==== Outside of national politics, accusations of "nepotism" are made in instances of ''[[prima facie]]'' favoritism to relatives, in such cases as: * [[Peaches Geldof]]'s role as magazine editor in an [[MTV]] reality show – produced by a company owned by her father [[Bob Geldof]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/showbiz/showbiznews/2008/03/16/peaches-geldof-bags-tv-reality-show-as-magazine-editor-98487-20353319/ |title=Peaches Geldof bags TV reality show as magazine editor |publisher=Sundaymirror.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524020700/http://www.sundaymirror.co.uk/showbiz/showbiznews/2008/03/16/peaches-geldof-bags-tv-reality-show-as-magazine-editor-98487-20353319/ |archivedate=May 24, 2008 }}</ref> * [[Tori Spelling]]'s breakout role on [[Beverly Hills 90210]] as a result of her father [[Aaron Spelling]]'s involvement with the show.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/30/arts/television/on-so-notorious-tori-spelling-mocks-herself-before-you-can.html|title=On 'So Notorious,' Tori Spelling Mocks Herself Before You Can|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/tori-spelling-admits-getting-shannon-doherty-fired-from-beverly-hills-90210-and-lending-her-dress-stained-with-virgin-blood-for-photoshoot-31580540.html|title=Tori Spelling admits getting Shannon Doherty fired from Beverly Hills 90210 and lending her dress stained with 'virgin blood' for photoshoot - Independent.ie|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} * Hollywood's [[Coppola family tree|Coppola family]] includes many distinguished filmmakers and actors. The careers of [[Sofia Coppola]], [[Nicolas Cage]], and [[Jason Schwartzman]] have been attributed to aid by director [[Francis Ford Coppola]], who cast his daughter Sofia in ''[[The Godfather Part III]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/EXTRA_Nepotism_in_the_Directors_Chair/312221 |title=EXTRA: Nepotism in the Director's Chair at |publisher=Hollywood.com |date=2000-04-21 |accessdate=2011-03-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006085336/http://www.hollywood.com/news/EXTRA_Nepotism_in_the_Directors_Chair/312221|archivedate=2012-10-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://spiritof1976.livejournal.com/338603.html |title=Nothing is true, everything is permitted - Coppola nepotism hate |publisher=Spiritof1976.livejournal.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> Cage changed his last name in order to distance himself from such charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000115/bio|title=Nicolas Cage|website=IMDb|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref>
== Selected examples by country ==
=== Australia === [[Anna Bligh]], who won the 2009 Queensland State election, has been accused of nepotism by giving her husband Greg Withers a position as the Office of Climate Change head.<ref name="houghton">Houghton, Des (2008-06-28). [http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,23931778-5012449,00.html "Anna Bligh's Labor in trouble in the polls"] ''Couriermail'', 28 June 2008. Retrieved 2009-08-17.</ref>
Shortly after his appointment as the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney in 2001, [[Peter Jensen (bishop)|Peter Jensen]] was accused, in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation interview, of nepotism after nominating his brother [[Phillip Jensen]] as Dean of Sydney and appointing his wife Christine Jensen to an official position in the Sydney diocese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s728866.htm |title=AM - Archbishop Jensen accused of nepotism |work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=2002-11-18 |accessdate=2012-06-22}}</ref>
=== Azerbaijan === On 21 February 2017, [[President of Azerbaijan]] [[Ilham Aliyev]] appointed his wife [[Mehriban Aliyeva]] to be [[Vice President of Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meeting of Security Council held under chairmanship of President Ilham Aliyev VIDEO|url=http://azertag.az/en/xeber/1037089|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Azertag|date=21 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>
=== Belgium === Over the past decade, criticism has been growing over the creation of political dynasties in Belgium, in which all of the traditional political parties have been involved. This phenomenon has been explained by the fact that prominent party members control the ranking of candidates on party lists for elections and a candidate's place on a list determines whether or not he or she is elected. Another justification for the phenomenon is the importance of name recognition for collecting votes.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/3376470/__Politiek_Belgie_is_familiezaak__.html?p=7,1 |title=Politiek België is familiezaak - Buitenland - Telegraaf.nl [24 uur actueel, ook mobiel] [buitenland] |publisher=Telegraaf.nl |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref>
Claims of nepotism have been made against [[Bruno Tobback]], the son of senator and former minister [[Louis Tobback]], a member of the Flemish socialists, became the Belgian federal government's minister for the pensions and environment at 35 in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ipe.com/magazine/tobback-making-his-mark_17630.php#.UcPF2ZzgUoI | title=Tobback: making his mark | publisher=IPE International Publishers Limited | work=Investment & Pensions Europe | date=1 Mar 2005 | accessdate=20 June 2013 | author=Martin Hurst}}</ref> [[Alexander De Croo]], the son of former speaker of the Belgian parliament Herman De Croo, ran for the leadership of his father's party Open VLD at age 33.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/binnenland/aid874229/alexander-de-croo-wil-voorzitter-open-vld-worden.aspx?cmt=all |title=Alexander De Croo wil voorzitter Open Vld worden |publisher=Gva.be |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> Finally there is the example of [[Maya Detiège]], the daughter of former mayor of the city of [[Antwerp]] Leona Detiège, who herself is the daughter of the former mayor of [[Antwerp]] Frans Detiège.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Among other examples are former minister Freya Vandenbossche and senator Jean Jacques De Gucht, being the daughter and son of respectively former minister Luc Vandenbossche and former minister Karel De Gucht.
=== Cambodia === Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]] and senior members of [[Parliament of Cambodia|Parliament]], are also known for their hand in getting family members into government positions. In the [[Cambodian parliamentary election, 2013|2013 Cambodian parliamentary elections]], at least eight candidates standing in the upcoming July election are sons of high-ranking [[Cambodian People’s Party]] officials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/2013050665421/National/sons-of-the-party-anointed.html |title=Sons of the party anointed |publisher= Meas Sokchea |date=2013-05-06 |accessdate=2013-05-06}}</ref> All ruling party sons lost, but were appointed into high government positions.
=== China === {{See also|Princelings}} For the past 3,000 years, nepotism has been common in China's clan and extended family based culture. Confucius wrote about the importance of balancing "filial piety with merit". The [[clan]]-based [[feudal society|feudal system]] collapsed during [[Confucius]]' lifetime, yet nepotism has continued through the modern age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1548234/high-level-officials-monopolise-party-promotion-mechanism-study-finds|title=High-level officials monopolise party promotion mechanism, study finds|date=6 July 2014|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Adam Bellow|title=In Praise of Nepotism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z8wSCZG9O6AC&pg=PA89|accessdate=21 June 2013|date=13 July 2004|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4000-7902-5|pages=89–92}}</ref> For instance, {{ill|Zhang Hui|zh|张辉|vertical-align=sup}}, was believed to have his career "expedited" through the intervention of his uncle, [[Li Jianguo]], Vice Chairman and Secretary General of the [[National People’s Congress]]. Hui was made the youngest member and secretary of Jining's Municipal Standing Committee at the age of 32.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/china-news/politburo-member-accused-of-nepotism-325972.html | title=Chinese Politburo Member Accused of Nepotism | work=The Epoch Times | date=18 December 2012 | accessdate=21 June 2013 | author=Fang Xiao}}</ref>
=== France === In October 2009, [[Jean Sarkozy]], the second son of the President of the French Republic [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], was poised to become the director of the major {{ill|Établissement public pour l'aménagement de la région de la Défense|lt=EPAD|fr}} authority despite lacking any higher education degree and professional experience.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE59F1AH20091016 |title=Poll shows majority against job for Sarkozy's son |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 2009-10-16|accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> In 2008 he was voted regional councillor of [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]], the town of which his father had previously been mayor.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://dalje.com/en-world/sarkozys-son-climbs-new-rung-on-political-ladder/156683 | title=Sarkozy´s Son Climbs New Rung On Political Ladder | publisher=Kontineo oglašavanje d.o.o. | work=dalje.com | date=16 June 2008 | accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
In September 2009, [[Rapping|rap]]-producer [[Pierre Sarkozy]], the first son of then President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], asked {{ill|SCPP|fr|Société civile des producteurs phonographiques|vertical-align=sup}} for a financial contribution of around €10000 towards an €80000 artistic project. Because he was not a SCPP member, the request was automatically rejected. Pierre Sarkozy then went to the [[Élysée]] which led to an Élysée aide contacting the SCPP, and SCPP president [[Marc Guez]] assuring the issue would soon be favorably resolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electronlibre.info/+Nepotisme-et-Sarkozysme-acte-II,02317+ |title=Népotisme et Sarkozysme, acte II (màj) |publisher=Electronlibre.info |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rue89.com/2009/11/07/apres-jean-un-coup-de-pouce-de-lelysee-pour-pierre-sarkozy-125100 |title=Après Jean, un coup de pouce de l'Elysée pour Pierre Sarkozy |publisher=Rue89.com |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> According to {{ill|Abeille Music|fr|Abeille Musique|vertical-align=sup}} president and SCPP member Yves Riesel, however, this would not happen as SCPP's financial help has been restricted to members only for months.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liberation.fr/politiques/0101601841-apres-jean-l-elysee-se-met-au-service-de-pierre-sarkozy |title=Après Jean, l'Elysée se met au service de Pierre Sarkozy |publisher=Liberation.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref>
=== India === Corruption goes hand in hand with nepotism in India. It goes on in government and private jobs both. Nepotism is common in politics, business and in the movie industry. It goes on even in religious circles, arts, industry, and other types of organizations. Many members of parliament and the Legislative Assembly have a generations-long legacy of nepotic allocation of constituencies to their relatives. The [[Bajaj Group|Bajaj]] family is related to the [[Birla family]] which itself is related to the [[Kishore Biyani|Biyani]] family by marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.ndtv.com/photos/business/the-family-connections-of-india-inc-14191|title=The family connections of India Inc|publisher=}}</ref> The [[Kapoor family|Kapoor families]], and many other Indian movie actors have brought their children into the movie industry with their endorsement. The successful actress Priyanka Chopra (now international) said in an interview that she was kicked out of a movie (which was originally offered to her) because of nepotism. Moreover, dynasty in politics remains. [[Rahul Gandhi]], Vice-President of the [[Indian National Congress]] party, is a descendent of [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] and [[Indira Gandhi]] & [[Rajiv Gandhi]]. Cricket is also affected with nepotism in the form of [[Stuart Binny]] and [[Rohan Gavaskar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/12/world/asia/12iht-letter12.html|title=Across India, Nepotism as a Way of Life|date=12 April 2012|work=International Herald Tribune|via=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/nepotism-the-way-they-do-politics-in-india-20140327-zqnpg.html|title=Nepotism: the way they do politics in India|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
=== Romania === [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romanian Communist]] dictator [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]]'s family members "dominated" the country for decades.<ref>{{cite book|author=Adam Bellow|title=In Praise of Nepotism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z8wSCZG9O6AC|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=13 July 2004|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4000-7902-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Edward Behr|title=Kiss the hand you cannot bite: the rise and fall of the Ceauşescus|date=21 May 1991|publisher=Villard Books|isbn=978-0-679-40128-5|page=175}}</ref> [[Elena Băsescu]], the daughter of President [[Traian Băsescu]], was elected in 2009 to the [[European Parliament]], despite the fact that she had no significant professional or political experience.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ziare.com/articole/elena+basescu+nepotism | title=Search on Elena Băsescu nepotism | work=Zaire.com | accessdate=21 June 2013 }}</ref>
=== Singapore === Singapore's government has been the target of numerous charges of nepotism, with several members of the Prime Minister's family holding high posts. The family members dispute the charges as they arise.<ref>{{cite news | title=Singapore’s Lee Family and Nepotism |date=24 February 2012 |url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/society/singapores-lee-family-and-nepotism/ |newspaper=Asia Sentinel}}</ref>
=== Spain === [[Juan Antonio Samaranch Salisachs]], son of [[Juan Antonio Samaranch]], president of the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) from 1980 to 2001, has been a member of the International Olympic Committee since 2001, and his daughter, Maria Teresa Samaranch Salisachs, has been president of the Spanish Federation of Sports on Ice since 2005.<ref name="ElPais">{{Cite news | title = La larga carrera de un hombre polifacético | url = http://www.elpais.com/articulo/deportes/larga/carrera/hombre/polifacetico/elpepudep/20100421elpepudep_9/Tes | newspaper = El País | date = 21 April 2010 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}. {{es icon}}</ref>
Nepotism occurred in [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spanish Colonial America]] when offices were given to family members.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Alan R. Freitang, Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|author2=Ashli Quesinberry Stokes|title=Global Public Relations: Spanning Borders, Spanning Cultures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kPrOtG3lv0QC&pg=PA208|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=22 December 2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-06129-7|page=208}}</ref>
=== Sri Lanka === {{See also|Rajapaksa family}} Former President of Sri Lanka, [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]], has been accused of nepotism, appointing three brothers to run important ministries and giving out other political positions to relatives, regardless of their merit. During his presidency, the Rajapaksa family held the ministries of [[Ministry of Finance and Planning (Sri Lanka)|finance]], [[defence minister|defence]], [[Ministry of Ports and Aviation (Sri Lanka)|ports and aviation]], and [[Ministry of Highways and Road Development (Sri Lanka)|highways and road development]]. The president's brother, [[Gotabhaya Rajapaksa]], was given the post of [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Defence Secretary]]. He also controlled the armed forces, the police and the Coast Guard, and was responsible for immigration and emigration. Rajapaksa appointed his brother [[Basil Rajapaksa]] as minister of [[Ministry of Youth Empowerment and Socio Economic Development (Sri Lanka)|Economic Development]]. Together, the Rajapaksa brothers controlled over 70% of Sri Lanka's public budget. Mahinda Rajapaksa's eldest brother, [[Chamal Rajapaksa]], was appointed as the [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka]], and has held many other posts before, while his eldest son, Namal Rajapaksa, is also a member of the parliament and holds undisclosed portfolios.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.economist.com/node/9299003?story_id=9299003 | work=The Economist | title=A war strange as fiction | date=2007-06-07}}</ref><ref name="atimes1">{{cite web|author=Nov 11, 2010 |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/LK11Df02.html |title=Asia Times Online :: South Asia news, business and economy from India and Pakistan |publisher=Atimes.com |date=2010-11-11 |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref>
Others include: his nephew, [[Shashindra Rajapaksa]], who is the former [[Chief minister of Uva]]; one of his cousins, former Sri Lankan ambassador to the [[United States]], [[Jaliya Wickramasuriya]]; and another cousin, [[Udayanga Weeratunga]], who is the former ambassador to [[Russia]]. Dozens of nephews, nieces, cousins, and in-laws have also been appointed as heads of banks, boards, and corporations.<ref name="atimes1"/>
=== United Kingdom === In February 2010, Sir Christopher Kelly, chairman of the [[Committee on Standards in Public Life]], said that more than 200 MPs used Parliamentary allowances to employ their own relatives in a variety of office roles. He suggested that the practice should be banned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8520548.stm|accessdate=27 August 2011|date=17 February 2010 | work=BBC News|title=Ban on MP spouse jobs 'essential'}}</ref>
In 2005, Councillor Ann Reid of York arranged for all nine sets of traffic lights on her daughter Hannah's wedding route through York to be switched to green for the five-car convoy, to test a system whereby traffic lights would turn green if there was an incoming emergency vehicle. As a result, the wedding party took only 10 minutes to pass through the city.<ref>{{cite news|title=Councillor turns lights green for daughter's wedding | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1500864/Councillor-turns-lights-green-for-daughters-wedding.html | date=18 October 2005 | accessdate=2011-12-09 | newspaper=The Telegraph | location=York, UK | last=Stokes | first=Paul}}</ref>
North Yorkshire Police's Chief Constable [[Grahame Maxwell]] was disciplined by the IPCC in 2011, but refused to resign, after admitting that he assisted a relative through the first stages of a recruitment process.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Chief constable remains despite calls for resignation | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-york-north-yorkshire-13369301 | newspaper=BBC News | location=North Yorkshire, UK | date=12 May 2011 }}</ref>
Many Northern Irish politicians employ family members. In 2008, 19 elected politicians of the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) directly employed family members and relatives constituted 27 of its 136 staff.<ref>{{Cite news | title = DUP's two tribes | url = http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/politics/dups-two-tribes-13387086.html | newspaper = [[Belfast Telegraph]] | date = 22 February 2008 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
=== United States === [[Palm Beach County, Florida]] schools reinforced nepotism rules as of 2012 to ensure an "equitable work environment".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2012-04-12/news/fl-nepotism-palm-schools-20120412_1_nepotism-relatives-indirect-supervision|title=Palm Beach County School Board reinforces nepotism rules|work=tribunedigital-sunsentinel|access-date=2017-05-12|language=en}}</ref>
In December 2012, a report from the [[Washington Post]] indicated various nepotism practices from the [[District of Columbia]] and Northern [[Virginia]]'s [[Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority]] (MWAA), including one family with five members working for the MWAA. One of the reasons given by the associate general counsel to defend the alleged nepotism was “if [the employees are] qualified and competed for [the positions] on their own, I don’t see a problem with relatives working in the same organization.”<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomson|first=Cheryl W.|title=D.C. airport authority employment is frequently a family affair|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/dc-airport-authority-employment-is-frequently-a-family-affair/2012/12/08/e29ab88a-3eef-11e2-a2d9-822f58ac9fd5_story.html|accessdate=10 December 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=8 December 2012}}</ref> The inspector general of the U.S. [[Department of Transportation]] and the U.S. Congress pressured the MWAA to resolve practices of nepotism. Authority employees are no longer allowed to directly or indirectly influence hiring or promotion of relatives, as documented in their ethics policy.<ref>{{cite news|author=Editorial Board |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/airports-authority-must-clean-up-its-act-on-nepotism/2012/12/10/dc217b7a-4308-11e2-8061-253bccfc7532_story.html |title=Airports authority must clean up its act on nepotism |publisher=The Washington Post |date= 10 December 2012|accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref>
In 2016, [[Philadelphia 76ers]] chairman of basketball operations [[Jerry Colangelo]] named his son [[Bryan Colangelo]] his general manager without a thorough search for the position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crossingbroad.com/2016/04/reports-nepotism-to-replace-sam-hinkie-as-sixers-gm.html|title=Reports: Nepotism to Replace Sam Hinkie as Sixers GM|work=Crossing Broad}}</ref>
==== Politics ==== Around 30 family members or relatives of President [[Ulysses S. Grant]] prospered financially in some way from either government appointments or employment.<ref>{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of white-collar & corporate crime, Volume 2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=P41ij0GoFL4C&pg=PA374&lpg=PA374&dq=James+Watson+Webb+Scandal+in+Brazil#v=onepage&q=James%20Watson%20Webb%20Scandal%20in%20Brazil&f=false|author=Lawrence M. Salinger|pages=374–375|volume=2|year=2005 |isbn=9780761930044}}</ref>
[[John F. Kennedy]] made his brother-in-law, [[Sargent Shriver]], the first director of the Peace Corps and his brother, [[Robert F. Kennedy]], Attorney General.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jeffrey M. Elliot|author2=Sheikh R. Ali|title=The PresidentialCongressional Political Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ppIIbWkftv4C&pg=PA88|accessdate=20 June 2013|date=1 September 2007|publisher=Wildside Press LLC|isbn=978-1-4344-9140-4|page=88}}</ref>
In 1979, [[Bill Clinton]], within weeks of being newly elected as Governor of Arkansas, appointed his wife [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] to chair of the Rural Health Advisory Committee.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Kelly (editor)|title=The First Couple: A Union of Mind and Ambition |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/01/20/us/the-inauguration-the-first-couple-a-union-of-mind-and-ambition.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=20 January 1993 |accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> In 1993, newly elected as President of the United States, he again [[Hillary Clinton#Health care and other policy initiatives|appointed]] his wife to chair a Task Force on National Health Care Reform.
In 2017, the president-elect [[Donald Trump]] appointed his son-in-law [[Jared Kushner]] as a senior adviser to the president <ref>{{cite news|author=Alan Yuhas |title=Trump names son-in-law Jared Kushner as senior adviser, testing anti-nepotism law |date=10 January 2017| newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/09/jared-kushner-senior-adviser-donald-trump}}</ref> He then announced on 29 March 2017 that his eldest daughter, [[Ivanka Trump]], would also become an official White House employee.
Both the Clinton and Trump presidential appointments have raised ethical and legal questions about whether they conflict with a 1967 federal anti-nepotism law.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ailsa Chang |title=Jared Kushner And The Anti-Nepotism Statute That Might Keep Him From The White House |date=November 18, 2016| newspaper=NPR.org |url=http://www.npr.org/2016/11/18/502637785/jared-kushner-and-the-anti-nepotism-statute-that-might-keep-him-from-the-white-h}}</ref>
In 2002, after his election to and swearing in as [[Governor of Alaska]], [[Frank Murkowski]] appointed his daughter [[Lisa Murkowski|Lisa]] to the United States Senate seat he resigned from to take office as Governor.
=== Venezuela === Nepotism is known to be practiced by former President of the Venezuela National Assembly, [[Cilia Flores]]. Nine positions in the National Assembly were filled by Flores' family members, including a mother-in-law, aunt, 3 siblings, a cousin and her mother, and 2 nephews.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-aLXTLBNASEC&pg=PA71|title=The Naked Truth|date=6 April 2011|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=978-1-4568-8753-7|page=71|author1=Emmanuel Adetula|author2=calibre (0.7.50)|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/18/world/americas/18iht-venez.html?_r=0|title=Chávez family dogged by nepotism claims|date=18 February 2007|work=The New York Times|accessdate=20 June 2013|author=Simon Romero}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2008/07/08/pol_ava_cilia-flores-niega-i_08A1777279.shtml|title=Nacional y Política - eluniversal.com|date=|publisher=Buscador.eluniversal.com|language=es|accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref>
=== Zimbabwe === Until his 2017 deposement, President [[Robert Mugabe]] was reported to be preparing his wife [[Grace Mugabe]] to be the next president of Zimbabwe once he steps down.<ref>{{cite web | last=Thornycroft | first=Peta |last2=Blair |first2=David | title=Mugabe accused of 'bedroom coup' as he prepares his wife for presidency | publisher=The Telegraph | date=31 October 2014 | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/11201716/Mugabe-accused-of-bedroom-coup-as-he-prepares-his-wife-for-presidency.html | accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref> Vice President [[Joice Mujuru]] was previously considered to be the favored successor to Mugabe.<ref>JR ASAP BEATZ,ASAP PRESS</ref>
== Types of partiality == Nepotism refers to partiality to family whereas [[cronyism]] refers to partiality to an associate or [[friend]]. [[In-group favoritism|Favoritism]], the broadest of the terms, refers to partiality based upon being part of a favored group, rather than job performance.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.scu.edu/ethics/practicing/focusareas/government_ethics/introduction/cronyism.html | title=Favoritism, Cronyism, and Nepotism | publisher=Santa Clara University | accessdate=June 20, 2013 | author=Judy Nadler and Miriam Schulman}}</ref>
